description.narrative: Strengthened capacities of government and producer institutions to design, develop and deliver key services and Mainstreaming & operationalization of Disaster Risk Management policy.
seat of a first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Community level autonomous adaptation in Ethiopia
Community level autonomous adaptation in Ethiopia
Community level autonomous adaptation in Ethiopia
Community level autonomous adaptation in Ethiopia
Community level autonomous adaptation in Ethiopia

description.narrative: Access to technologies and practices that improve the range and efficiency of adaptation options improved
of farmers adopting adaptation technologies by technology type disaggregated by gender

comment.narrative: Farmers 83 maleheaded 17 femaleheaded currently constrained by limited access to and knowledge of adaptation techniques and practices

By the end of the project 5000 subsistence farmers 83 maleheaded 17 femaleheaded have been trained in and tested climate change resilience building techniques and practices of which 35 of both male and female headed farming households have adopted them permanently

In order to improve farmers access to technologies and practices that have adaptation value the project has provided material inputs as well as technical backstopping for beneficiary farmers and for communal actions undertaken for the purpose of environmental rehabilitation of forests or pasturelands catchment management Thus in this reporting period in all project sites
Climate resilient conservation agriculture and crop diversification practices with the use of drought resistant crop varieties implemented Small scale irrigation to grow market demanding fruits and vegetable crops through using rainwater harvesting technologies low cost drip irrigation systems human powered semi rotary water pumps and small to medium sized solar generated water pumps were implemented improved bee keeping technologies and practices for honey and wax production that could improve the productivity and quality of the produce were supported by provision of modern beehives and accessories livestock production mainly goat and sheep production and fattening programme were implemented Development and use of household biogas energy and also production and use of energy efficient stoves were undertaken Environmental and natural resources management through area closure construction of physical soil conservation measures forest tree planting and other similar practices were undertaken
In order to enable farmers and woreda and kebele officials test the prioritized adaptation measures and technologies practical trainings were provided and an experience sharing field demonstrations were organized by the project to a total of 832 399 F 433 M farmers 40 Developments Agents DAs and 44 woreda Task Team members The trainings focused mainly on different CC adaptation technologies including Climate resilient agricultural crop and vegetable production practices Modern and environmentally friendly animal husbandry mainly goat and sheep husbandry and fattening practices modern apicultural practices including small scale irrigation using rain water harvesting techniques shallow well drilling and application of solar pumps and by applying drip irrigation techniques river diversion techniques rehabilitation of degraded ecosystems production and use of energy efficient stoves and use of house holds level biogas energy production and use Following the trainings a total of 4479 2547 male which is 5094 of the target and 1932 female which is 3864 of the target farmers have been implementing above mentioned CC adaptation technologies and actions on their farm plots as an integrated set of adaptation actions on a total of 1200 hectares of land across all sites

description.narrative: Capacity for communitybased climate change adaptation improved
of targeted population covered by innovative insurance mechanisms disaggregated by gender

comment.narrative: Informal coping strategies are in use in target areas no formal financial risk reducinginsurance approaches yet in place due to lack of meteorological and hazard information in target areas
By the end of the project at least 25 of the men and 25 of the women in the target communities are using innovative mechanisms to insure against the inherent uncertainty of climate change

In order to facilitate the access to climate information which is considered as a constraining factor in reducing vulnerability to the perceived seasonal unpredictability of weather in all the PAA project sites including in Addis Ababa different activities have been performed in this reporting period Support was provided to the National Meteorological Agency NMA to present its available downscaled weather forecast information which could be used for seasonal projections andor longer term climate related projections for risk planning to target Woreda level planners and beneficiary farmers in a way that they can find it useful and gather feedback in a way that improves their own forecasting In order to create awareness and sufficient understanding to Woreda planners DAs and Kebele level officials on downscaled weather data and on how to interpret this data to climate information and adjust their interventions and disaster risk management plans different training sessions were organized by the project to a total of 1128 487F 641M participants from across the project sites Due to the these trainings Woreda and local level awareness about the issue has increased substantially and about 3896 female and 5128 male target beneficiary communities have started using climate data effectively in their decision making processes Thus in general the average growth of productivity in all production items is estimated to grow by 300 from the baseline production level across all pilot sites This shows that there has been an increased production by 2875 than when compared to the expected target set at the end of the project period Due to this increase in productivity beneficiary farmers income has increased and substantially supported their livelihood

description.narrative: Institutional capacities for coordinated climateresilient planning and investment strengthened

Number and type of targeted institutions with increased adaptive capacity to minimise exposure to climate vulnerability
Capacity perception index disaggregated by gender

comment.narrative:
Capacity for climaterelated analysis and forward planning is limited at subnational level with an average CCA capacity score of 126 across the 5 functional areas of
Multistakeholder dialogue
Situation analysis vision casting and mandate
Policy and strategy formulation
Budget Manage and Implement
Monitoring and Evaluation

By end of Project 4 Woreda and 1 Regional task teams have been trained in and use climate related vulnerability and risk assessments in an integrated areabased planning approach
Average CCA capacity score in the 4 Woreda and 1 Regional level is 3 for both men and women

As followup practice from year 2014 the project continued providing training and mentoring support to all the 4 pilot rural Woredas and the 8 Kebele pilot sites as well as in Addis Ababa city government Accordingly in this reporting period training and mentoring support was provided to 264 79 F 185 M Woreda level task team members including planning experts local level government representatives and local community members The trainings have focused on how to Engage in multistakeholder dialogue Assess a situation and create a vision and mandate Formulate implementation policy and strategy Budget manage and implement the planned intervention and Monitor and evaluate progress and feed back into the implementation management After the trainings those who participated in the trainings have used the knowledge to undertake climate related vulnerability and risk assessments in an integrated areabased planning approach in their respective Woredas the Woreda Task teams used the skills and knowledge they acquired from the training and undertook climate related vulnerability and risk assessments in an integrated areabased planning approach in their respective Woredas Apart from training support Simple pictorialbased information sheets on climate change its causes and effects designed for local community consumption was prepared and have been distributed to local level decision makers planners and extension agents in order to facilitate easy access to climate change related information Capacity building support was also provided to 54 8 F 46 Male in the 4 rural Woreda and to 15 1 F 14 M task team members in Addis Ababa project task team members to prepare areabased climate vulnerability profiles and climate risk analyses using GIS tools as part of the learning by doing approach for the development of the integrated plans After the training task team members have been able to undertake vulnerability assessment and produce local level vulnerability maps and documents for their respective localities All in all it could be said that the institutional capacity score has increased from the baseline score of 126 to 285

description.narrative: To support local communities and administrations at the lowest level of government to design and implement adaptation actions aimed at reducing vulnerability and building resilience especially in those communities that are particularly vulnerable in Ethiopia
Capacity perception index disaggregated by Gender

comment.narrative: Average CCA capacity scorecard rating of 126 across men and women
CCA capacity scorecard rating is increased to an average of 3 in target Woredas for both men and women

Since the inception of the project implementation the project has been providing different capacity building trainings to enhance institutional capacity at lowest administrative levels mainly at the 4 Woredas and the 8 Kebeles Mesebo Mesret kebeles in Enderta woreda Selga 23 Kushmengel kebeles Asossa woreda Desta Abijata Kemo Gerbi kebeles in Adami Tulu Jido Kombolcha woreda and PukongPimoli kebeles in Gambela Woreda on how to engage in multistakeholder dialogue assess situation create a mandate and vision formulate policy and strategy budget management and implementation as well as monitoring and evaluation Based on this support task team members have been able to design and provide mentoring support to beneficiary community members at the Kebele level in integrating and implementing new CC adaptation techniques and technologies Furthermore beneficiary farmers have gained practical knowledge on participatory planning methods In so doing capacity in properly designing and implementing CC adaptation measures that would reduce vulnerability and build the resilience of local communities to climate change in the PAA pilot Kebeles and in Addis Ababa has improved In general the institutional capacity is improved for a total of 333 88 F245 M woreda task team membersDA agents Woreda task teams from the baseline 126 to 285 score
